linkTarget.anchoringText: El-Morgan Field (Figure 01) was discovered by the drilling of the El-Tor-1 well in February, 1965. Two oil productive zones were found. Subsequently, these two zones were identified as the Belayim formation and Kareem formation (Figure 02). The drilling of second and third wells confirmed the commercial viability of the oil discovery. Production operation commenced on April 12, 1967. As of May 1, 1968 there were 17 producing wells in the field, and drilling operations were continuing.

image-wrap.label: Figure (01)
image-wrap.caption: Location Map of El-Morgan Field, Gulf of Suez, Egypt

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location Map of El-Morgan Field, Gulf of Suez, Egypt

linkTarget.anchoringText: El-Morgan Field (Figure 01) was discovered by the drilling of the El-Tor-1 well in February, 1965. Two oil productive zones were found. Subsequently, these two zones were identified as the Belayim formation and Kareem formation (Figure 02). The drilling of second and third wells confirmed the commercial viability of the oil discovery. Production operation commenced on April 12, 1967. As of May 1, 1968 there were 17 producing wells in the field, and drilling operations were continuing.

image-wrap.label: Figure (02)
image-wrap.caption: Structure Contour Maps for Kareem and Belayim Formation, El-Morgan Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Kareem (Figure 04) is medium-coarse grained, poorly sorted arkosic sands inter-bedded with laminated shales. Normal grading is common, and individual sand bodies sometimes show coarse erosive bases, resulting in sand stacking and good vertical communication. Sands are sheet-like and no evidence is seen for channelization. The Kareem likely consists of a series of overlapping lobes that were strongly influenced by rift-bathymetry.

image-wrap.label: Figure (04)
image-wrap.caption: Open Hole Log Example for Kareem and Belayim formation, Morgan Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Open Hole Log Example for Kareem and Belayim formation, Morgan Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: High production rates from Kareem reservoir resulted in a rapid pressure decline (Figure 05) which caused a rapid increase in Gas-Oil Ratio (GOR) due to the high bubble-point pressure as well. This reservoir performance indicated that the underlying aquifer was not active enough to support production operations at high rates. As a result, GUPCO initiated evaluating the possibility of Water Injection in late 1970 to increase reservoir pressure and improve the production rate.

image-wrap.label: Figure (05)
image-wrap.caption: Pressure Performance of South El-Morgan Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure Performance of South El-Morgan Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: From 1975 through 1990, many wells had been drilled in Kareem reservoir with high withdrawal rate which in turn needs higher pressure support. That's why in mid-1990, Waterflooding strategy is changed; Infill-injectors were started to be used in addition to the peripheral injectors. This strategy resulted in a better Waterflooding efficiency for both displacing and sweeping the oil. It is noteworthy that the infill injectors were placed carefully in a manner helping in minimizing the bypassed oil. Figure (06) shows the wells status during that period.

For Example, a base line RST was performed on the subject well (Figure 07) and after one year, another RST was run to determine the new saturation distribution. The second RST showed that the water saturation increase in the middle part indicating a possible high permeable strike. A third RST was run after two years and showed the movement of the bottom aquifer compared to the high permeable strike. Eventually this time-lapse process of logging gave us a very good shape regarding the dynamic reservoir behavior and helped in taking the right decision on the right time.

One of the most common problems in dealing with Waterflooding is presence of high Permeability layers causing the water flood-front to be unsteady (or fingers out) (Figures 13 & 31). That's why Thermally-Activated Particles (or Polymers) TAP is used to somehow plug this high perm layer, and helps in directing the water into the unswept layers (Figures 31 & 35).

linkTarget.anchoringText: To control such factor, GUPCO usually uses "pipeline health map" (Figure 17) to monitor the condition of each pipeline. We also assign the reserve related to each pipeline whether this pipeline is Oil, water, gas or even chemical line. This approach helps us a lot to understand the importance and to set the priority for each pipeline and decide whether to scrap, mothball or repair any of them (Figure 18).

image-wrap.caption: Example of Pipeline Health Map in July field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example of Pipeline Health Map in July field

We also assign the reserve related to each pipeline whether this pipeline is Oil, water, gas or even chemical line. This approach helps us a lot to understand the importance and to set the priority for each pipeline and decide whether to scrap, mothball or repair any of them (Figure 18).

linkTarget.anchoringText: October field is located in northern part of Gulf of Suez (Figure 19). It was discovered in 1970 with estimated STOOIP 2.38 Billion STBO, It is producing mainly from four formations (Nubia, Nezzazat, Nukhul and Asl) via around 100 wells. October's peak production hit 180,000 BOPD, and current production rate is around 23,000 BOPD.

image-wrap.label: Figure (19)
image-wrap.caption: Location of October Field in GoS, and Structure Contour map for Nubia formation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location of October Field in GoS, and Structure Contour map for Nubia formation

linkTarget.anchoringText: Nubia formation is a high quality reservoir in terms of rock permeability. It is composed of four zones; TZ, MN, M1 and M2 (Figure 20). Their average permeability (air permeability from core plugs) is 100-300 mD, 200-500 mD, 500-1500 mD, 500-1000 mD respectively. That discrepancy in zones' permeabilities led to obvious vertical heterogeneity across Nubia zones.

image-wrap.label: Figure (20)
image-wrap.caption: Three water injectors' locations, and Type –log of Nubia formation showing zones (TZ, MN, M1 and M2)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Three water injectors' locations, and Type –log of Nubia formation showing zones (TZ, MN, M1 and M2)

linkTarget.anchoringText: After fifteen years of production, Nubia pressure hovered around the bubble point pressure. That's why Waterflooding started in 1996 to support the high offtake from Nubia wells by injecting in three wells (Figure 21) at that time (H11, G9 and G14). One of these injectors was dedicated to M2 zone only (G14) however the other two injectors were injecting in entire Nubia zones simultaneously.

image-wrap.label: Figure (21)
image-wrap.caption: Summary of Analytical tools had been used including performance (production & pressure), rock properties, fluid properties, injectors' performance and MB energy plot

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of Analytical tools had been used including performance (production & pressure), rock properties, fluid properties, injectors' performance and MB energy plot

linkTarget.anchoringText: Krigging simulation was used to generate iso-maps for oil cumulative and WC with time, and comparing them with the hydrocarbon pore volume (HCPV) map. By integrating all of these findings (Figures 24 & 25) with our understanding of aquifer strength and fluid movement, we came up with interesting conclusion; we have a huge volume of bypassed oil. Most likely reason behind that bypassed oil was injecting in bad locations! It is noteworthy that was consistent with the splitted production data (Figure 22) which showed possible bypassed oil is mainly in M1 zone, and also diagnostic plots that were used like Chan Plot which revealed channeling effect in most of Nubia wells (Figure 26).

By integrating all of these findings (Figures 24 & 25) with our understanding of aquifer strength and fluid movement, we came up with interesting conclusion; we have a huge volume of bypassed oil. Most likely reason behind that bypassed oil was injecting in bad locations! It is noteworthy that was consistent with the splitted production data (Figure 22) which showed possible bypassed oil is mainly in M1 zone, and also diagnostic plots that were used like Chan Plot which revealed channeling effect in most of Nubia wells (Figure 26).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Summary of short-term action taken in October Nubia Redevelopment Study

linkTarget.anchoringText: In order to define optimum Waterflooding pattern and prize accurately, technical team recommended building a numerical reservoir model for entire Nubia reservoir (Figure 28) for three reasons: Quantify bypassed oil volume, Optimize recovery method and evaluate prize of polymer flooding. The study will be completed in first quarter of 2017.

image-wrap.label: Figure (28)
image-wrap.caption: Proposed long-term plan for October Nubia Redevelopment Study

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proposed long-term plan for October Nubia Redevelopment Study

image-wrap.label: Figure (30)
image-wrap.caption: Structure Contour Map for Morgan Kareem

formatted-caption.caption-text: Structure Contour Map for Morgan Kareem

linkTarget.anchoringText: One of the most common problems in dealing with Waterflooding is presence of high Permeability layers causing the water flood-front to be unsteady (or fingers out) (Figures 13 & 31). That's why Thermally-Activated Particles (or Polymers) TAP is used to somehow plug this high perm layer, and helps in directing the water into the unswept layers (Figures 31 & 35).

Normally these particles are injected in liquid phase with injected water, and then they get cross-linked when exposed to certain temperature for a certain period of time, and plug pore- throats of the flooded reservoir part (Figures 32 & 33). This technique is known commercially as BrightWater®.

Normally these particles are injected in liquid phase with injected water, and then they get cross-linked when exposed to certain temperature for a certain period of time, and plug pore- throats of the flooded reservoir part (Figures 32 & 33). This technique is known commercially as BrightWater®.

To maximize recovery, we need to direct the injected water into the other lower permeability layers (K1 and K3). So we have used streamline simulation to determine optimum treatment scheme, and we've applied the TAP technique to 5 WIW to affect 10 producers; three of them had oil gain around 400 BOPD. (Figure 34) represents profile of the total incremental oil gain expected from the TAP technique.

One of the most common problems in dealing with Waterflooding is presence of high Permeability layers causing the water flood-front to be unsteady (or fingers out) (Figures 13 & 31). That's why Thermally-Activated Particles (or Polymers) TAP is used to somehow plug this high perm layer, and helps in directing the water into the unswept layers (Figures 31 & 35).

image-wrap.label: Figure (35)
image-wrap.caption: Morgan Kareem Zones, and Streamline simulation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Morgan Kareem Zones, and Streamline simulation

linkTarget.anchoringText: In appraising LoSal™ technique, GUPCO conducted many core analyses on different reservoirs' samples in GoS to know what downside, most-likely and Upside cases are. In addition to that, we've also conducted SWCTT on the well M170-253 in Kareem reservoir, and results showed a reduction in (Sor) of 2 saturation units (SU). And at final, we came up with the prize range we'll use (Figure 36).

image-wrap.label: Figure (36)
image-wrap.caption: Impact of low salinity on Kr curve

formatted-caption.caption-text: Impact of low salinity on Kr curve

linkTarget.anchoringText: In general, LoSal™ showed an improvement in recovery factor (Figures 36 & 37) ranging from 21%from core-flood tests, up to 54% from single-well chemical tracer tests (SWCTT).

Low Salinity Waterflooding uses water with less than 8000 PPM TDS. And regarding its mechanism, Let's assume we have a crude oil molecule attracted to the surface of rock grain via "thin film" and a bridging "divalent cation" in red (Figure 38). Normally High Salinity Waterflooding increases the "Adhesion Force" between the crude oil molecule and the surface (bounded oil).

We've selected a sector model (Figure 39), and we have QC'ed it assuring it captures the degree of heterogeneity we'd like to mimic, and then we history-matched it. We've run special algorithm to relate saturation to its adequate relative permeability curve to simulate LoSal™ impact.

image-wrap.label: Figure (39)
image-wrap.caption: Numerical simulation model to estimate LoSalTM at field scale

formatted-caption.caption-text: Numerical simulation model to estimate LoSalTM at field scale

linkTarget.anchoringText: And as a result we succeeded to obtain the LoSal™ incremental prize at reservoir scale as shown in (Figure 40) with its uncertainty.

Our first recommendation is to use SWOT Matrix technique in planning any job, study or project. SWOT matrix includes four sections: Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities and Threats. It helps to define barriers, take the vision and set achievable goals. For example, in planning a LoSal™ project, we've identified this (Figure 41). SWOT matrix changes from company to another even for the same project that's why each single case should have its own matrix.

GUPCO used to use benchmarking in order to compare fields' observations with industry best practice. For example, (Figure 42) compares WOR vs. (Np) plot for GUPCO reservoirs (which are in colored lines) with North Sea fields which are in black lines. And here we can see that GUPCO observations are similar and even better in some cases.

image-wrap.label: Figure (42)
image-wrap.caption: Benchmarking example for (WOR) vs. (Np) Plot – GUPCO vs. North Sea.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Benchmarking example for (WOR) vs. (Np) Plot – GUPCO vs. North Sea.
